discussion.content:
The fourth answer should be: 
Run the New-MailboxRestoreRequest cmdlet

just change last one to: New-MailboxRestoreRequest
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/high-availability/disaster-recovery/restore-data-using-recovery-dbs?view=exchserver-2019
Correct order, just change the last one: New-MailboxRestoreRequest
The last task should be New-MailboxRestoreRequest

For me:

Restore Database
eseutil /d
create recovery database
new-mailboxrestorerequest
shouldn't 'create recovery database' be a first action? then recover from backup?

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization that contains a Mailbox server named MBX01.
You back up MBX01 by using Windows Server Backup.
You need to recover a deleted mailbox. The solution must minimize the impact on other mailboxes.
Which four actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization named litwareinc.com.
The organization publishes Exchange services by using a namespace of mail.litwareinc.com.
You deploy a new server named EX10 to the organization.
User reports that sometimes they receive warnings about certificate errors when they connect to their mailbox. The warning message reference is ex10.litwareinc.com.
You need to resolve the issue.
How should you complete the command? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization that contains four Mailbox servers and one Edge Transport server. The organization supports hundreds of remote users.
You need to block offline access to Outlook on the web for all the users.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
Correct answer is:
<Run the Set-OWMailboxPolicy cmdlet and specify the parameter "AllowOfflineOn NoComputers>

comments.content: Sorry, ignore the above. B is correct as it says all users. Not sure what I was reading. :(
No it means there is a typo in this copy of the test

Me again.. lol. The command in B has a typo Set-OW(missing a)MailboxPolicy. Should be Set-OWAMailboxPolicy. Then does that mean C is the next possible solution as the command in B won't work? Sorry, just trying to get my head around this. :)

discussion.content: I believe the answer is correct here as the requirement is for remote users only. If you run command as per B then doesn't that block offline for all users (internal/external)?

comments.content: Edge Transport has nothing to do with client access as per TripletCaptain post. "B" it is.

I misunderstood the question and I would like to correct myself. "B" is the correct answer. Set-OWAMailboxPolicy can work on both on-premise and the cloud. Set-OWAVirtualDirectory can only be used on-premise.

discussion.content: I believe "C" is correct. It states they want to block "offline" access which can be controlled by the Edge server. Internally OWA would be accessible.
The edge transport server has nothing to do with OWA client access (or any other client access) - the operative term here is "TRANSPORT".

choices.A: Run the Set-OWMailboxPolicy cmdlet and specify the parameter ""ExplicitLogonEnabled $true
choices.D: On each Mailbox server, run the Set-OwaVirtualDirectory cmdlet and specify the parameter. ""ExternalURLs $null
choices.C: On the Edge Transport server, run the Set-OwaVirtualDirectory cmdlet and specify the ""AllowOfflineOn NoComputers parameter.
choices.B: Run the Set-OWMailboxPolicy cmdlet and specify the parameter ""AllowOfflineOn NoComputers

choices.D: Add User1 to the Server Management group.
choices.C: Add User1 to the Delegated Setup group.
choices.A: Add User1 to the Organization Management group.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization that contains a server named EX01.
You plan to deploy a new Mailbox server named EX05.
You need to ensure that a user named User1 can install Exchange Server 2019 on EX05. The solution must use the principle of least privilege.
Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content: User1 must be added to the Delegated setup group after ex05 is provisioned

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization named litwareinc.com.
The organization publishes Exchange services by using a namespace of mail.litwareinc.com.
You deploy a new server named EX10 to the organization.
User reports that sometimes they receive warnings about certificate errors when they connect to their mailbox. The warning message reference is ex10.litwareinc.com.
You need to resolve the issue.
How should you complete the command? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:

discussion.content: Correct command is Set-ClientAccessService in Exchange 2019

both ellichen and jojo are right, rif: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/client-access-servers/set-clientaccessservice?view=exchange-ps
and
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/client-access-servers/set-clientaccessserver?view=exchange-ps
Set-ClientAccessServer is still valid but it should be Set-ClientAccessService. And should be used moving forward.

Since the answer is missing:
Set-ClientAccessServer -Identity EX10 -AutodiscoverServiceInternalUri "https://mail.litwareinc.com/autodiscover/autodiscover.xml"
